column13:
> since 1985 noone has been killed by a legally owned fully automatic

Yeah, because in 1986 they put a law in place that banned the sale of new ones and legally keeping a grandfathered one required registration, extensive background checks, an approval signature from a chief law enforcement official, a $200 tax stamp, and filing a request for approval with the ATF if you ever wanted to sell it to someone else.  Which all adds up to a waiting period of anywhere from 3 to 12 months to obtain one, on top of all the paperwork necessary to obtain it in the first place.

In other words, no one has been killed by a legally owned fully automatic since we enacted strict rules regulating who was allowed to legally own a fully automatic.
There have only been 2 homicides with them since 1934.

it is a Massachusetts house bill proposed to prevent the upgrading and modification of firearms. In the bill it speaks to prevent the owner from adding a lubricant to a firearm. the bill is H3979 filed on 10/26/2017. look it up

Was it one of these two passages? (neither say oiling a gun is a felony, but this is all I saw mentioning firearms)

41 SECTION 18. Chapter 140 of General Laws is hereby amended by inserting after section 
242 131Q, as appearing in the 2016 Official Edition, the following section:
243 Section 131R. Whoever possesses, owns or offers for sale any device which attaches to a 
244 rifle, shotgun or firearm, except a magazine, that is designed to increase the rate of discharge of 
245 the rifle, shotgun or firearm or whoever modifies any rifle, shotgun or firearm with the intent to 
246 increase its rate of discharge, shall be punished by imprisonment in the state prison by not less 
247 than 3 nor more than 20 years.


511 SECTION 51. The Secretary of Public Safety shall promulgate regulations by January 1, 
512 2018 concerning the allowability of maintenance and enhancement of rifles, shotguns and 
513 firearms consistent with the intent of this section.

What, that's it?  Talk about fearmongering.  If that makes it illegal to oil a firearm, then hand-lotion is a "device" which "attaches" to your hands and "modifies" your skin.  If that sounds stupid, that's because it is.  These terms do not cover a substance which is applied for the regular care and maintenance of something.

and if it's this part that's supposedly spooking gun-nuts:
"The Secretary of Public Safety shall promulgate regulations by January 1, 2018 concerning the allowability of maintenance and enhancement of rifles, shotguns and firearms consistent with the intent of this section."

What that means is the secretary of public safety is going to produce and distribute rules regarding the care and maintenance of firearms, and outline which enhancements are permitted and which are not.  It doesn't say a single word about what those rules are going to be, that's being left up to the secretary of public safety to decide.

so, no.  it doesn't make it a felony to oil a firearm, and any reputable lawyer would find that interpretation laughable.
The ATF classified a shoelace as a machine gun for over a decade. You can find it laughable for all you want, it can still happen

Anything beyond fear mongering, though?  At this point it appears that someone is just trying to scare you with hyperbolic stories and counting on the likelihood that you won't check.  You really think they made oiling a gun a felony?  Or do you think maybe a fear monger conflated those two passages and pretended something absurd was going on to generate some click bait?

Garrett Holland I looked it up.  Apparently that was because the legislation itself (which was written in the 1930s, so, make of that what you will) specified that any part used to convert a weapon into a machinegun was a machinegun in and of itself.  ie it defined "machinegun" to include "any part designed and intended solely and exclusively...for use in converting a weapon into a machinegun."  The shoelace in question most certainly was designed and intended that way; the stupidity was in the law being written such that a single part could be classified as a machinegun on its own, before being added to the weapon.

Anyway even if you do classify oil as a "device", it does not "attach" to a firearm (if it can't *de*tach then it can't be *a*ttached), and it does not "modify" the firearm - an oiled rifle is still performing its function as intended by the manufacturer.  And further still, even if you assume it does "modify" a firearm, it is not used with the intent to increase the firearm's rate of discharge, it's used with intent to reduce wear on the internal mechanisms of the firearm.  

In short, even if you stretch the definition really, really far, it's still difficult to arrive at the conclusion that this bill would make it a felony to oil a firearm.
Read the sentence in context and replace oil with own.
So you're just outright making up new stuff to be scared of?  WTF?

Uh, it's been used to make ownership of certain KINDS of firearms illegal, but with the 2nd amendment in place there's no way legislation will ever be able to make ALL firearms illegal to own.  The supreme court has consistently ruled that the 2nd amendment means you get to own a gun.  That's not going away.  A couple legislators in Massachusetts aren't going to overturn over a century worth of judicial precedent.

And just because a bill makes one thing illegal, doesn't mean you can logically assume intent to make all related things illegal.  It's illegal for me to drive a car without insurance, but I don't see anyone trying to make it illegal to drive cars at all.

There are plenty of examples where legal rulings and the government breaking its own laws.  For example it is federally illegal to keep a registry yet we have state registries depending on state and of course a federal registry of firearms due to the NFA.

Garrett Holland I mean, it's actually not illegal to own any specific firearm on a federal level.  There are no small arms which are outright banned federally.  There are just very strict rules about who's allowed to own or purchase one, and it's mostly just a lot of paperwork and an extra tax.

Even if everyone in the government woke up tomorrow and decided to make all semi-automatic rifles subject to the same regulations as machineguns, you would not suddenly be a criminal for owning whatever ones you own.  Because - shock - the supreme court upheld your 5th amendment right against self-incrimination after someone was charged with possession of an unregistered machinegun when he went to register the one he already owned.  This resulted in the law being amended to remove the requirement for possessors of unregistered firearms to register them, and added a provision stating that any information disclosed on an NFA application/registration cannot be used against you as evidence for being in violation of the law prior to filing the form.  In other words, if you owned an unregistered Tommy gun for 40 years and then decided to register it because you wanted to sell it legally, you could not be charged with unlawful possession of a machinegun based on admitting you owned one via filing your forms.  Guess what, the 2nd amendment isn't the only right used to protect other rights.  In addition to the 5th you'd also be protected under the 4th - unreasonable search and seizure.   The feds can't come in and ransack your house just because they think you might have an unregistered NFA firearm.

So don't worry, buddy.  You'll be fine.

1911GreaterThanALL
> For example it is federally illegal to keep a registry yet we have state registries depending on state and of course a federal registry of firearms due to the NFA.

It's illegal to keep a universal federal registry, it's not federally illegal to keep a registry.  There's a difference.  The first makes it illegal for the federal government to keep a national registry, the second makes it illegal for anyone to keep a registry.  States are allowed to have their own registries.

Also the law that prevents establishing a federal registry specifies that it only applies to regulations enacted after the date the law goes into effect.  Any registry legally established before that law is exempted, including the NFA registry.  So no, the government is not breaking its own laws there.

> TYT claiming that there is no regulation on firearms when we do have significant gun controls and they don't work - it is just less than other countries.

1: We have less gun control than other countries
2: Countries with more gun control than us have less gun violence than we do
Yeah, clearly gun control doesn't work.  There must be some other reason that countries with stricter gun control have less gun violence, it's certainly not because our "significant" measures aren't adequate, or because we have a patchwork system of regulations applied inconsistently across state lines.  1+2 = 5, I guess.

The NFA is grandfathered in as any registry law prior to this is legal if there was an attempt to have a registry any time after 1968 then yes it would be FEDERALLY illegal to do so many states are in violation.

Perhaps the moron is the one who cannot understand why the slippery slope fallacy is a fallacy.
Baron von Quiply it's not a fallacy.

Lee, natural rights don't require someone to prove anything to anyone to exercise. When someone has done something wrong, we punish them by taking away certain natural rights. It's what we have to do to maintain society. But once they've served their time, they have paid their debt in full. As such, their rights should be reinstated in full.

Baron, a slippery slope can be a fallacy, but anytime someone argues progression doesn't inherently mean they're committing a logical fallacy. In the case of gun rights, we can see in history with the passing of the 1934 NFA and the 1986 FOPA that laws at the time which seem innocuous can later be used to ban. Therefore, given that there is a clear history of this progression having occurred, arguing the point is not a slippery slope fallacy.

Human rights are things like being able to worship whatever deity you want or not being murdered because of who you are, or having real access to food, water, housing, education, and healthcare, or the right not to live under a tyrannical government. The ability to own a weapon, a gun in particular, is not a natural right because all those things existed long before the concept of a firearm was ever even a thing. Those are all things every human instinctively understands. Being able to live freely and to make a living and to get an education are way more important than the privilege of owning a weapon.

Oh, and another thing: the fact that everyone in America is packing heat is not even in the top 5 on the list of reasons America is unlikely to be invaded. #1 on that list is the fact that we have the strongest military in human history. #2: Our closest neighbors are Canada and Mexico who won't screw with us because of aforementioned military and the fact that it's much more beneficial for all of us if the continent isn't at war with itself. #3: Anyone else who would want to screw with us would have to cross an ocean to actually put boots on the ground. We'd see it coming from a mile away. Guns are not as important as we seem to believe they are.

column5:
RANCHO TEHAMA RESERVE, Calif. — The shooting is over in Rancho Tehama, but the nightmare continues for Troy McFadyen.
He still vividly remembers the shooter running him off the road, methodically killing his wife, Michelle, shooting him twice and leaving them both in a ditch by the side of the road.
“I’m still having moments of flashbacks thinking about that truck coming toward me, just missing me,” McFadyen said. “And being shot and watching my wife.”

McFadyen was in Mercy Medical Center in Redding on Sunday recovering from his wounds, shot once in each leg. Both bones in his lower right leg were shattered by a bullet fired by Kevin Janson Neal.
McFadyen was one of 17 people Neal shot last Tuesday, according to the Tehama County Sheriff’s Office. Neal killed four people and wounded 13 others before he, too, was shot and killed by deputies.
The day before the shooting the 44-year-old Neal killed his wife and stuffed her under the floor of their Rancho Tehama home, officials said.
On Sunday, McFadyen was in his hospital room with visitors, including a brother, two sisters and a friend.
He wondered how it all could have happened, and why someone who was not supposed to have firearms shot and wounded him and gunned down his wife in the small rural community 15 miles southwest of Red Bluff.
“You know it’s a problem when I can’t just drive into town without getting shot,” he said.
McFadyen said he and his wife were driving out of town Tuesday morning for a doctor’s appointment when they saw a white pickup coming down the road toward them. The driver crossed into the oncoming lane, as if to crash head-on into the McFadyens.
Troy said he crossed over into the oncoming lane to avoid the truck, but it mirrored his maneuver.
As the truck got near, he swerved back over and the pickup hit his Ford Crown Victoria just behind the driver’s door, T-boning it.
The crash spun them around, but sent the truck crashing down an embankment and through a fence. He wasn’t able to open his door to get out of the car, so he and his wife got out through the passenger side.
“Just as I got outside of the vehicle the gunfire started, from the nearest we could tell it was down the hill, (from) this truck that just went in the gully,” he said.
“I look over my car, (over the roof) and look down the hill and this guy is drawing a bead with his pistol … He starts firing in our direction and I say to my wife ‘Run! Run! Let’s go!’” he said.
“We’re panicked and the gunfire is just coming, he’s coming up the hill, firing his gun,” he said.
McFadyen and his wife became separated. She fell in a ditch, while he headed up Stagecoach Road on foot.
He looked up and saw the man firing at him. One of the bullets hit his left leg and went through his thigh.
The shot stung, but he could still walk. A car drove by and McFadyen tried to get them to let him in, but they locked their doors and drove off, he said.
As McFadyen ran, Neal shot him in the right lower leg, shattering bones.
He fell in the road and tried to sit up. At that point, Michelle McFadyen came up the road toward him and Neal began firing at her.
“She becomes his new focus, I guess. She falls in the ditch and he walks up rather casually and puts two rounds in her. All the while I’m screaming, ‘Please don’t! Please don’t!’” McFadyen said.
After shooting his wife, he turned toward McFadyen. Michelle made a noise, so he turned back and shot her at least two more times, he said.
“So after he shoots her a second time he turns around and starts coming toward me again. At which point I lay back on my back and I say ‘I’m dead! I’m dead! I’m dead!'” McFadyen said.
He remembers looking the man in the eye as he came toward him. McFadyen had never seen him before, but he remembers seeing his pickup.
“He was calm, methodical,” he said. “I looked at him right in the face, just another creepo.”
He appeared to lose interest and walked back down the road and got into a gray car. McFadyen said he wasn’t sure where the gray car came from.
Neal drove up the road in the gray car toward McFadden as if he was going to run him over. McFadyen, however, was able to pull himself off the road and down into the ditch near his wife.
Neal drove off out of sight. The gunman's next stop was the Rancho Tehama Elementary School, according to the sheriff's office.
“We’re finally left alone, and I’m screaming for somebody to help because it seemed like I could have been on the moon,” he said.
After a few minutes, Christopher Bradford, the attendant at the nearby garbage transfer station, came to his aid. Bradford stayed with McFadyen until law enforcement arrived and drove him in his garbage truck to where paramedics could help him.
“Everyone else drove off, but not Chris. He’s a hero,” said Troy’s brother, Mike McFadyen. “Probably the only hero out there, and he works at the dump.”
Troy McFadyen estimated he was in the ditch waiting for help for about two hours. He was eventually flown out and taken to Mercy Medical Center.
He isn’t sure if he will be released from the hospital before Thanksgiving. And even after his release, he expects months of rehabilitation on his leg.
But he will be learning to walk again without his wife. Sunday he became angry thinking about how she was killed for no apparent reason by a stranger.
Before going to work in social services for Shasta County, she was a teacher who worked many years to help children. Troy McFadyen said he often worried about his wife working in downtown Redding.
“I talked to my wife a couple times a day because we really loved each other, and I always ended my calls with ‘Be safe,’” he said.

column13: This is as absurd as saying we shouldn't have laws against homicide, because 'criminals will never follow those laws'. Australia's 1996 laws have resulted in no mass shootings in 20 years; criminals have been deterred by the hoops they have to jump through to get guns. The shooter in cases like these would be less likely to have a gun in the first place.

A well read Congress, being necessary to the wise operation of government, the right of the people to own and read books, shall not be infringed.

We have a duty to make sure that the government is not powerful enough for the people to fear. Limiting or banning assault rifles is giving the government that power to become tyrannical. These are the reasons to not ban assault rifles.

+1911: Since 1996, Australia has experienced no mass shootings; the number of prohibited firearms accounted for clearly means very little. Suicide rates, and to some extent homicide rates, have gone down, saving many, many lives: http://www.smh.com.au/national/health/the-rate-of-all-suicides-and-homicides-in-australia-has-declined-since-the-gun-buyback-20160622-gpp4wp.html

Being an island has little to do with anything. Plenty of non-island countries have implemented gun control. Yes, countries like Japan place a focus on the well-being of society as a whole, and there's no reason the US can't do the same. If you're arguing we're unlikely to do this in the near future because we're selfish pricks ("individualists"), sure. But we can and should change.

Lastly, you're imagining some scenario where gun control is implemented by a mechanized Robama overlord. But we're talking about implementing it with the will of the people, this isn't going to start a civil war. Minds can be changed over time. Although I'll take a guess that the real issue isn't about how easily this can be accomplished, but simply that you don't think minds should be changed on this issue, because you think guns are somehow a good thing. They're not. We have 75,000 gun injuries per year, 21,000 suicides, and 11,000 homicides. Massively reducing gun prevalence could cut these numbers by the thousands, and having easier access to your hobby is not more important than saving/bettering those lives.

+Elijah: The massive number of guns out there is misleading, since most guns are owned by 'super-owners' who own a bunch. The actual number of people who own guns is, by one estimate, around 37%: http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2013/06/04/a-minority-of-americans-own-guns-but-just-how-many-is-unclear/ People are not manufacturing them illegally in great quantities in Australia or Japan, so there is no evidence to think this would have to happen here.

Australia's gun buyback bought 660,000 firearms; a US one, dealing with a much bigger population, could potentially get more if it were seriously pursued. Perhaps we wouldn't get any from the fanatical super-owners, but we could potentially buy back the guns from people who only own one or two, knocking that 37% down a peg. That would be only one facet of gun control. Other facets would include mandatory safety classes, a really long cooling off period after purchase, proper gun storage and police inspection at times, licensing systems, etc.

The drug/gun comparison isn't valid. People truly crave drugs and have a biological need for them. But as countries like Japan, Australia, the UK, etc, have shown, people don't have an addiction to own guns; large black markets haven't formed like they did for alcohol during Prohibition.

Japan, Australia, the UK, etc, haven't become any more tyrannical than they already were. So there seems to be no correlation between gun control and 'tyranny level'.

nexus1g yeah, but i was specifically talking about 1911's remark that a national gun registry has been prohibited for hundreds of years.  It's only been prohibited since 1986 when legislation was passed which prohibited it.

Mandatory registration is a different issue.  That's the issue of whether individuals can be mandated to add themselves to a registry, which was what the 1968 decision was about.  The 1986 law prohibits the registry itself from existing.

Guindo, he's right that it's been illegal for hundreds of years. It was illegal from the time the Second and Fifth Amendment were ratified. And registries weren't made illegal in 1986. The NFA registry was closed to ban the sale of automatic arms to civilians. That's it.

Uh, no, it wasn't, because wanting to keep track of who owns things is not an infringement on your right to own the thing.  The DMV requires me to register my car with them and keeps a registry of who owns what cars, but I still have every right to own that car if I want to and it's not illegal for me to own and keep an unregistered car on my own property, it's only illegal for it to operate on a public road.  If you want to argue that it's unconstitutional that's one thing, but unconstitutional doesn't mean illegal; laws can be unconstitutional. That's the entire purpose of the judicial branch of our government, deciding whether a law is unconstitutional or not.

"unconstitutional doesn't mean illegal"

Yeah, it actually does. In fact the Constitution is called the Supreme Law of the Land. It literally says in Article 6, Item 2, "*This Constitution*, and the Laws of the United States which shall be made in Pursuance thereof; and all Treaties made, or which shall be made, under the Authority of the United States, shall be the supreme Law of the Land; and the Judges in every State shall be bound thereby, any Thing in the Constitution or Laws of any State to the Contrary notwithstanding."

Alright, I'll concede that.  The idea I was getting at was that laws which are unconstitutional can exist, and people will be bound by those laws and prosecuted under those laws just the same as any other, until the law's constitutionality is challenged and decided in court.  Even then, that decision only applies within that court's jurisdiction, so a law declared unconstitutional by one circuit can be declared constitutional by another one.  Those conflicting rulings would stand until the law went up to the SCOTUS for a final, nationwide decision.

A fairly recent example: in 2014, several different circuits, including the 9th, had ruled same-sex marriage bans unconstitutional, but the 6th decided they were constitutional.  So it was illegal to ban same-sex marriage in Oregon, but legal to ban it in Ohio, due to the courts having differing interpretations of the constitution.  It wasn't until the constitutionality got determined by the SCOTUS that such bans became illegal nationwide.

That's what I meant by saying unconstitutional doesn't mean illegal.  A law can be unconstitutional and illegal in one state but constitutional and legal in another state; a law doesn't actually become illegal to enforce nationwide until the Supreme Court says so.  Until then, it may be unconstitutional, but it hasn't been declared such, so the law remains legal to enforce.

Thus, if the SCOTUS has not heard a case and ruled that state gun registries are unconstitutional, then such registries remain legal for those states to have and enforce.  If a circuit appeals court has heard & decided a case stating that they are unconstitutional, then such registries only become illegal in the states within that circuit, and remain legal in states outside of it.

So if you want to convince me that state/local gun registries are unconstitutional and therefore illegal and therefore the government breaking its own laws, you're going to have to show me a SCOTUS case where they determined them to be unconstitutional.

I think I understand where you're coming from in a way, because you're saying that in practice a law isn't actually acted upon as though it were illegal until a high court states it. The problem is, if that were the case, then those prosecuted under the law would continue serving their original sentences after the ruling because the law wouldn't have been considered unconstitutional for practical purposes until the court ruled on it. Instead, a law exists with an inherent property of whether or not it's constitutional. The courts only determine whether that inherent property is true or false, but it doesn't give it that property. If the court gave it that property, it would only be practicable from that point on, but all prior actions taken would be considered constitutional.

Yeah, you got it, that's exactly what I'm trying to say. I don't quite think your logic disputing it follows, though. 

So, when a law is declared unconstitutional, it usually doesn't automatically reverse any convictions under the law ("non-retroactive" is the default for these decisions, though the court can decide to make them retroactive during its ruling).  But you can appeal to have your conviction overturned, and if you wouldn't have been convicted under the new, revised law, then your conviction will be overturned.  Obviously, that's because the thing you did never should have been illegal in the first place because the law should never have existed.

So, in a way you are correct that laws have an inherent property of constitutionality that a court determines the nature of.  But at the same time, that property isn't objective because the courts must interpret the constitution and different people interpret it differently, so something that's constitutional now may be ruled unconstitutional 30 years later when a case is revisited.  And it could theoretically be revisited another 30 years later by a new court and be declared constitutional again.  So it's a sort of schroedinger's constitutionality, where it is both constitutional and unconstitutional until it is observed, and treated as constitutional by default until declared otherwise.

So in other words, whether or not YOU feel something is unconstitutional, it's not actually illegal until the COURT says it is.  Because THEIR interpretation of the constitution is the one that determines the law, not yours.  Do you see what I'm saying?

Guindo, that's my ignorance of how the courts work. I thought all cases completed based on laws deemed unconstitutional required mandatory review. That really is disconcerting that you can pass whatever silly law you want, and it doesn't have to be at all constitutional for it to affect people's lives.

Yup.... And even scarier that it essentially all comes down to the combined legal opinions of 9 people appointed by various presidents for lifetime terms.  That's the real reason your vote matters.

Like, I think voter ID laws are a clear violation of the equal protections clause because they prevent poor people from voting (getting a state ID is basically impossible if you don't have official copies of your birth certificate, marriage license/court order for name changes, social security card, etc and can't afford a $30 processing fee for each copy and the ID itself).  But clearly the SCOTUS didn't agree and now we have several states with these blatantly (imo) unconstitutional laws preventing people from exercising a basic right.  But they're legal and allowed to stand because SCOTUS said so.

Has SCOTUS ever heard a gun-registry case?  I can't imagine the NRA wouldn't have tried to push one to SCOTUS if they really thought they had a case for unconstitutionality.  I'd look into that.

Guindo, the majority opinions and dissents written by the justices can be so painfully partisan too. I would love to see what Hamilton, Jefferson and Madison thought of what has evolved from their republic and if they would agree with it or disagree.

Nexus, I am right there with you, man.  I would absolutely love to see what the founding fathers would think of what's going on right now.  I especially wonder what they'd say about the entire second amendment argument vs our numbers of gun deaths.

I mean, the best small-arms technology they had back then was the flintlock mechanism, which couldn't fire reliably or at all in damp weather and required manual reloading where you had to put powder in the flash pan and stuff the shot down the barrel with a ramrod, and 4 rounds per minute was considered fast - sometimes too fast, since the guns would misfire if any burning powder was left in the barrel when you put the new powder in.  The next big advancement in firearms tech was the percussion cap around the 1820s, but it still required manual reloading, it just turned the flash pan powder into a self-contained cartridge.  So even then, best tech was still 4 rounds per minute, it was just a more consistent and reliable, all-weather 4 rounds per minute.  And then revolvers, the next big improvement which took the human reloading time out of the equation and allowed several shots fired in a row, those weren't widely available until the late 1830s when Samuel Colt patented a reliable cylinder mechanism and started mass-producing them.

So when they wrote that the government shall not infringe upon the right to keep and bear arms, the most advanced small arms they could imagine was one that improved on the flintlock - a 4 RPM rifle or musket that could fire in the rain and maybe wouldn't misfire if you reloaded it too fast.  And the last founding father died the same year Colt patented his revolvers, so they were all dead before anyone could ever expect that the average American would be able to fire more than 1 shot without taking at least 10 to 15 seconds to reload the next one.  Double-action, spring-loaded magazines, semi-auto, burst fire, full-auto - they couldn't even have predicted any of that, or the problems we'd have 200+ years later because one single sentence out of a 5,000 word document wasn't written clearly enough and didn't explain how "well-regulated" and "shall not infringe" were supposed to reconcile with each other.

It makes me wonder if they would've written that differently, had they known that someday Tommy guns and AKs and AR15s would exist, and that evil people would use them to terrorize, harm, and kill thousands of innocent people per year.  Would they feel they should have clarified their intent more?  That they should have defined what "well-regulated" meant, or clarified the expectation of keeping a militia, or specified what kinds of arms people had the right to keep and bear, or where they could be kept, or specified that they shall not be infringed "without due process of the law," or...? Or would they, like we have, accept that those lives are simply the cost of preserving a free republic, and change nothing?

I'm sure we both have our own opinions on that, and they're probably very different, but neither one is any more or less valid than the other because we just can't know without being able to ask them.  So.  I think about that a lot.

Don Rutter....  I think you may have pulled those numbers straight out of your anus

Fact: The 2A is an individual right unconnected to service in a militia.

Fact: There are 320 million people in America but only 628,000 police officers. (But we all know the Left hates police)

Fact: A recent National Association of Chiefs of Police survey found that 86.4 percent of 20,000 police chiefs and sheriffs support concealed carry and are overwhelmingly against further gun control. 

Fact: According to the Centers for Disease Control, which found that gun ownership increased by 56 percent, and yet gun violence declined by almost 50 percent 

Fact: A Nov. 26, 2013 study found that, between 1980 and 2009, "assault weapons bans did not significantly affect murder rates at the state level" and "states with restrictions on the carrying of concealed weapons had higher gun-related murders.

Fact: Senator Dianne Feinstein, a gun control advocate, carried a concealed gun when her life was threatened and her home attacked by the New World Liberation Front in the 1970s. 

Fact: According to the CDC's "Leading Causes of Death Reports," between 1999 and 2013, Americans were 21.5 times more likely to die of heart disease (9,691,733 deaths); 18.7 times more likely to die of malignant tumors (8,458,868 deaths); and 2.4 times more likely to die of diabetes or 2.3 times more likely to die of Alzheimer's (1,080,298 and 1,053,207 respectively) than to die from a firearm (whether by accident, homicide, or suicide). [4] The flu and related pneumonia (875,143 deaths); traffic accidents (594,280 deaths); and poisoning whether via accident, homicide, or suicide (475,907 deaths) all killed more people between 1999 and 2013 than firearms. 

Fact: Japan has a low gun ownership rate at 0.6 guns per 100 people and a high suicide rate of 18.41 suicides per 100,000 people in 1997 (ranking it 11 out of 71 countries). South Korea has a low gun ownership rate (1.1 guns per 100 people) but has a high rate of suicide and the highest rate of gun suicides (12.63 per 100,000 people in 1997). By contrast the United States has the 26th highest suicide rate (12.3 suicides per 100,000 people in 2011) and the highest gun ownership rate (88.8 guns per 100 people).

Fact:Mexico has some of the strictest gun control laws in the world and yet, in 2012, Mexico had 11,309 gun murders (9.97 gun homicides per 100,000 people) compared to the United States that had 9,146 gun homicides (2.97 per 100,000 people).

Fact: Gun massacres are not the only or even the most lethal form of gun violence.

Fact: A ban on military-style weapons of the kind used in the two most recent high-profile gun massacres and in so many others before—wouldn’t have an effect on gun violence in America, which tends to be concentrated on handguns.

"Like most rights, the Second Amendment right is not unlimited. column5: We must improve the gun control we already have in place. If someone already is going through a background check said background check should actually be a reliable method of detecting and predicting future misuse. Right now, innocent people have to wait through these background checks for a long while yet they don't actually provide accurate results consistently. We need to make the background checks as efficient is possible to save time and resources while also ensuring factors such as mental illness, past abuse, criminal record, etc. are being accounted for in a meaningful way. Also, multiple organizations must be accountable for record keeping and updates. Said process should be taken extremely seriously. I think if all of that is implemented innocent people should still be able to own various forms of weaponry even if it doesn't make sense to some (AKA fast-firing, silenced, and high-caliber firearms and modifications). We need to be smart and take into account the desires of our citizens. One of which is freedom.

column5:
"You have bad actors doing terrible things. And so, instead of passing legislation that put a stop to that,  instead everyone else is going to be inconvenienced." ~ Ana Kasparian. That same argument is what gun proponents often use against supporters of gun control following mass shootings; namely that the ideas being bandied about won't actually fix/prevent the issue they seek to. For instance when Kimmel was targeting the "gun show loophole" following the Vegas shooting even though the killer has a clean criminal record and it wouldn't have changed anything. Or when there are calls to ban rifles when the vast majority of gun crimes and murders are with handguns.

There is also the way the media covers guns - With the Texas church shooting, the media would often describe the killer's gun as an "assault weapon" and at the same time describe the gun of the person who stopped him as a "hunting rifle" even though both of them used the same exact type of gun; namely an AR-15. As such, it's this slight of hand by the media that gun proponents also complain about; saying that it makes it difficult to have an honest conversation about the subject.

I find myself wondering why bills are not ironclad. This could be an almost simple process.
Draft the bill, join a leaflet describing the "spirit of the law". Get yourself 2 lawyers, one pro one con, give them simple instructions.
Pro : Make this watertight and redraft.
Con : poke this full of holes and submit for review.
Go a few rounds, make sure the Bill and the Spirit Leaf are still concurrent, done.

This might be very naive.

Have you read the proposed bill for the bump stock ban ?  (BILL HR3999) the definition of the subject of the bill is drunk in a foreign language at best.
I don't think anyone competent that had the slightest interest to see it made law read it. Ever.

Why lawyers and not politicians?

I will buy that but we would not require them debate for this.
Politicians are paid to politick, so let's just stick with that.
OK?

I don't really care who drafts the bill, actually. Not for the purpose of this discussion, anyway. The input of the lawyers would be to ensure that the text offers no alternative interpretation.
So why would I prefer lawyers to bullet-proof a bill ? Because of Legaleese. Politicians use their own lingo, but when one wants to circumvent a legal constraint, one gets a lawyer.
It looks a lot like Ro-Sham-Bo. Politician speak is often vague enough to bore loopholes in many texts. Legaleese is technical, precise, strives to eliminate double entendre and incertitudes ; Legaleese wins. My theoretical politician would hire the most vicious lawyers he/she could find to make his/her bill as unassailable, as unambiguous, as self sufficient, as rhetorically inert as possible. 
But again, this scenario will probably never happen. :)

Dirt:

Here's exactly how thing will play out with a transfer of liability over time.  

In the beginning, people will complain about it and the fact that they have to fill it out unless they want to be charged as an accessory in some fashion should the gun be used in a crime.

Over time, the number of guns being sold without the transfer of liability will drop.  As the number of guns without a proper paper trail diminishes due to being used in crimes and seized by the authorities or kept by collectors, the cost of those guns will increase.

As the cost of those guns increases, the number of them being used for crimes will decrease.  People who claim to be law abiding citizens but not want the government to "know what guns they have" will add to the scarcity of guns on the black market.

Eventually, a bare minimum circulation state will be reached in which only guns smuggled into the country or stolen from legitimate gun owners (who will hopefully report the theft, least they be charged) will be available to criminals and gun runners.

As the number of illegal guns and gun crimes diminishes, more and more people will support and adhere to the transfer of liability laws in order to protect their rights to own a gun legally.

In the end, gun violence will drop, illegal gun sales and trafficking will drop, and those law abiding gun owners can have a legitimate defense for legal gun ownership not being a constant cause for controversy.

Yes there will still be mass shootings and crazies, but the over all number of incidents and severity of most incidents will drop.

Who told you that BS nonsense? The FBI has three days to complete the background check process.
